RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN 2019 5-Year UPDATE



EXECUTIVE SUMMARY AND DATA ELEMENTS PACKAGE



CITY OF BENICIA WATER TREATMENT PLANT

100 WATER WAY

BENICIA, CALIFORNIA 94510



1.0 Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68), promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Article2, Chapter 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code (HSC), the City of Benicia (Benicia) submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their Water Treatment Plant (WTP) in Benicia, California.  Benicia provides potable water to their service area, which coincides with the city limits.  The facility is capable of treating 12 million gallons per day of water.



2.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Benicia is committed to protecting the health and safety of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore, it is Benicia's policy to manage a safe and healthy workplace, protect the environment and maintain compliance with safety, health, and environmental regulations: Federal Risk Management Plan (RMP), 40 CFR 68; OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM), 29 CFR Part 1910.119; and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program, 29 CCR, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  This commitment is demonstrated by the comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  It is the policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.

2.1 Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

Benicia is subject to the Federal Risk Management Plan (RMP) program because chlorine, a regulated substance, is present at the facility in amounts greater than 2,500 pounds.  Benicia is required to treat the water supply so that it meets or exceeds the drinking water quality standards of the C

alifornia State Water Resources Control Board-Division of Drinking Water.  Benicia uses chlorine to disinfect the water.  Benicia's chlorine disinfection process consists of one-ton chlorine containers, two chlorine secondary containment vessels, three chlorinators, and a piping system that is all under vacuum.  The process and storage cylinders can contain a maximum amount of 8,000 pounds of chlorine.

2.2 Worst-Case and Alternative-Case Release Scenario

This section has been deleted to comply with 2004 regulatory updates to address homeland security.  Information regarding the Offsite Consequence Analysis is located with the Superintendent at the City of Benicia, Water Treatment Plant.  A revised OCA was completed in September 2008 by Risk Management Professionals.



3.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps

The facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention program requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the stationary source.

3.1 Process Safety Information

Benicia Water Treatment Plant maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.

3.2 Process Hazard Analysis

Benicia has conducted comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is a What if/Checklist.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.  The most recent PHA update was performed on September 21, 2016, by WTP personnel.  On September 6, 2019, an independent audit was conducted by Risk Management Professionals. Delivery of audit is pending completion by Risk Management Professionals.

3.3 Operating Procedures

For the purposes o

f safely conducting activities within the covered process, Benicia Water Treatment Plant maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup.  The information is regularly reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.  Operating Procedures are reviewed annually for accuracy and pertinence.

3.4 Training

Benicia Water Treatment Plant has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every year and more frequently as needed.

3.5 Mechanical Integrity

Benicia Water Treatment Plant carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; containment vessels, one-ton chlorine containers, vacuum regulators, piping systems, relief and vent systems, leak and vacuum detectors, chlorinators and controls.  Maintenance operations are carried out by contracted personnel with qualified training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as required by the manufacturer.  Critical chlorine equipment is inspected and serviced annually.  Mechanical Integrity checks are conducted during chlorine change out and one-ton chlorine delivery.

3.6 Management of Change

Written procedures are in place at Benicia Water Treatment Plant to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  The most recent review/revision of management of change procedures was performed on September 21, 2016.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training

to deal with the modification.

3.7 Pre-startup Reviews

Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Benicia Water Treatment Plant.  The most recent review was performed during the month of June, 2017, when a structural walkdown was completed by Olweny and Associates Engineering.  Recommendations from this walkdown providing additional support to the chlorine eductor and injection system were completed on September 27, 2017.   These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.

3.8 Compliance Audits

Benicia Water Treatment Plant conducts audits on a tri-annual basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on September 21,2016.  This audit is located in the Risk Management Plan Inspection Report. Risk Management Professionals conducted a preliminary audit of the program on September 6, 2019.  The results of this audit are pending, and have not been delivered to the Benicia Water Treatment Plant for review.

3.9 Incident Investigation

Benicia Water Treatment Plant promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  There have been no accidents recorded since June 1999.

3.10 Employee Participation

Benicia Water Treatment Plant believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Agency employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, the employees have access to all information created as part

of the facility's implementation of the regulations, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.

3.11 Contractors

On occasion, Benicia hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and perform construction activities.  Benicia Water Treatment Plant has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures for emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.

3.12 Five-year Accident History

Benicia Water Treatment Plant has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to Benicia's stringent release prevention policies, there has been no accidental release during this period that caused any onsite death, injury or significant property damage, or known offsite death, injury, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.

3.13 Emergency Response Plan

Benicia Water Treatment Plant carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, the emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the processes that would require a modified emergency response.  As part of the Bioterrorism Act of 2002, the Emergency Response Plan was completed in March 2005 under the consultation of Security Concepts and Planning, LLC.
